subfields.b: welfare-to-work choices and challenges for states /
Distributed in association with the Welfare Information Network (WIN),

subfields.a: pt. I. The context of welfare reform. 1. Defining the goals of welfare reform. Why is welfare unpopular? -- What are the objectives of welfare reform? -- A focus on work -- The 1996 Federal Welfare Law: magnifying the need for effective work strategies -- 2. The starting point: welfare recipients, the labor market, and welfare as we have known it. Characteristics of welfare recipients : What are the demographic characteristics of welfare recipients? ; How long do people receive welfare? ; How many welfare recipients work, and how many could work? -- Characteristics of the labor market for low-skilled women : Are there enough jobs? ; What kinds of jobs are available to welfare recipients? -- Key features of the welfare system : How much is spent on welfare? ; How much does each family on welfare get? ; Has the welfare system discouraged work? -- What are the implications for welfare reform?

pt. II. Increasing work and self-sufficiency among welfare recipients: the research record. 3. Welfare-to-work programs. What can welfare-to-work programs accomplish, and what are their limitations? -- How do welfare-to-work programs affect government budgets and participants' financial well-being? -- Which works best: moving welfare recipients into jobs quickly, building their skills first, or using a mixed strategy? -- What other factors affect the success of welfare-to-work programs? -- What is the highest feasible rate of participation in a welfare-to-work program? -- What strategies work best for teenagers in households receiving AFDC? -- What are the biggest unanswered questions about welfare-to-work programs? -- 4. Mandatory work and subsidized employment. What are the basic approaches to mandatory work for welfare recipients? -- Why have there been so few large-scale work programs for welfare recipients? -- Do work requirements translate into "make-work" jobs? -- Do work requirements reduce welfare caseloads? -- Are work requirements cost-effective? -- What are the pros and cons of subsidizing employers to hire welfare recipients? -- Can work experience programs succeed with the most disadvantaged welfare recipients? -- What are the biggest unanswered questions about mandatory work? -- 5. Changing financial incentives. What are the key strategies for making work pay? -- What are the benefits and costs of make-work-pay policies? -- What factors might influence the effectiveness of a financial incentive program? -- What are the pros and cons of alternative strategies for making work pay? -- What are the biggest unanswered questions about policies for changing work incentives? -- 6. Time limits. What are the opportunities and risks of different approaches to time-limited welfare? -- How many people will reach time limits, and who will they be? -- What are the early lessons about operating time-limited welfare programs? -- What kinds of policies should be implemented along with time limits? -- What are the key unanswered questions about time-limited welfare?

pt. III. Conclusions. 7. Summing up. A summary: goals and tradeoffs -- The first step: clarifying goals -- The key challenges -- Common pitfalls -- New opportunities -- Appendix: Work-related provisions of the 1996 Federal Welfare Law -- Selected publications on MDRC projects.
